newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek air delays persist despite new radar.
newsitem.headline: Greek air delays persist despite new radar.

text.p: It takes a long time to fly to Greece. Think of the time you plan to get there, then add at least an hour.
Greek airports are notorious among international aircrews for their lack of modern infrastructure. Long delays persist despite recent installation of radar-assisted traffic control.

"It is probably too early to assess the efficacy of the new system because its introduction coincided with a surge in air traffic owing to the peak of the tourist season," said Eleftherios Vamvakoulas, secretary general of Greece's airline pilots association, EHPA.

"There are stark differences in flight delays among different routes," he added. "Domestic and outbound flights face delays of around 10 to 15 minutes, within internationally acceptable limits, whereas inbound flights are typically delayed for a minimum 60 minutes."
Airline sources said Greece has yet to improve flight control capacity despite starting work on a new $2.4 billion Athens airport due to open in February 2001.

However, last month Greece started to use the first segments of a radar network, supplied by France's Thomson-CSF at a total cost of around 25 billion drachmas ($90 million), to improve flight monitoring in its airspace, a long-awaited improvement which should eventually double flight capacity.
Until recently, Greek air traffic controllers handled flights through antiquated techniques based on position reports by airline pilots with the help of Distance Measuring Equipment (DME).

A secondary radar system which detects code-emitting transponders on aircraft has only an advisory role in Greece's air traffic control. Athens' Hellinikon airport is the only one fitted with a terminal approach radar.

"The new air traffic handling methodology is being deployed in steps and so far we are merely utilising some of its features," said Panagiotis Tsoumbelis, president of Greece's air traffic controllers association.
"It already offers a complete radar environment, but will take time before its operation is streamlined and staff training is complete, given current workload," he added.

"When the new system is fully functional, capacity levels may be doubled from current levels, "For the time being we're happy to maintain previous capacity levels despite the introduction and simultaneous use of the new system," he added. "International experience shows that such moves result in lower capacity figures."

In recent years, air traffic control has become fully integrated into the Brussels-based EuroControl centralised system which issues Calculated Take-Off Times (CTOT) to all aircraft ferrying passengers and cargo between European airports.
The new system is expected to contribute increased revenues to Greece's Civil Aviation Authority (YPA) which collects fees from airliners entering its Flight Information Region (FIR).

"When fully operational, the new system will be a great revenue booster, raising the number of users of Greece's air space and allowing for higher FIR entry fees through the offer of improved facilities to airliners," said Tsoumbelis.
"In any case, our entry fees are the lowest in Europe," he added. ($1 = 292 drachmas) --Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
